UPDATED: JUN 16, 2011 My Bottom Line:
Toasted malts and their caramelized undertow wash up on the tastebuds, leaving a fruity trail and spicy hop bitterness. This is a wonderful North American Altbier that¬ís not trying to be an amped-up version of the original style, for once.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A multi-layered head of foam laces all around the cloudy copper.
-The finish is probably my favorite part of the flavor profile; hop bitterness, toasted malt angles and light residual sugars coalesce beautifully.
-The flavor profile never gets boring. I love when beers pile up flavors with each sip instead of walloping you with all flavors at once. 
-Carbonation is ample and soft; a few bottles of this can disappear rapidly...
-This is not an overly simple and sweet version of the style. All flavors (and aromas) are intricate and harmonious from beginning to end.
-The nose starts off as timid when fresh out of the beer fridge, but reveals plenty of details upon warming up..
-Now if they could serve gravity-style from an oak cask. Just to compare it to D√ºsseldorf¬ís best, of course.
